title: Cheap Short-Living Objects
intent: Reduce risk and cost by using temporary, disposable, or easily replaceable elements instead of durable ones.

triz_principle.name: Cheap Short-Living Objects
triz_principle.definition: Replace expensive, long-lasting objects with cheaper, short-lived ones.

problem_understanding.core_contradiction: We want reliability and control, but long-lived solutions accumulate risk, rigidity, and maintenance cost.
problem_understanding.why_this_hurts: Permanent solutions attract hacks, exceptions, and hidden dependencies that are hard to remove later.
typical_signals: long-lived environments or configurations nobody dares to change
high cost to clean up experiments
fear of rollback because impact is too big

solution_logic.core_idea: Design components and processes to be temporary and disposable by default.
solution_logic.key_rule: If something is likely to change or fail, make it cheap to replace.
solution_logic.how_it_resolves_the_contradiction: Risk is limited in time and scope, enabling faster experimentation and cleaner evolution.

consulting: time-boxed initiatives instead of open-ended programs
pilot decisions with automatic expiration dates
temporary task forces instead of permanent committees
software_engineering: throwaway prototypes instead of over-engineered PoCs
architecture: stateless services that can be recreated anytime
enterprise_sap: temporary MDG rules for migration phases
sandbox systems instead of permanent special clients

anti_patterns: cheap components used in critical long-term paths

do_not_use_when: stability over long periods is required

diagnostic_questions: Which elements are expected to change soon?
What could be made disposable instead of permanent?

example.before: A pilot solution becomes a long-term dependency with no clear owner.
example.after: The pilot is explicitly temporary and replaced or removed after evaluation.
